choices.text: Superficial palmar branch of radial artery

questions.text: Superficial palmar arch is a continuation of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Superficial branch of ulnar artery

Ref: Read the text below

Sol :

The ulnar artery enters the hand & divides into superficial & deep branches.

The superficial branch continues as the superficial palmar arch. This arch is completed by one of the branches of radial artery,

a.    Arteria princips polices

b.    Arteria radialis indices

c.    Superficial palmar branch of radial artery.  

The radial artery itself continues as the deep palmar arch. It is completed by the deep palmar branch of ulnar artery.

questions.text: All are made of dense regular collagen except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Periosteum

Ref– Last’s Anatomy: Regional and Applied. - 6

Sol:

PERISOTEUM –

•    The outer surfaces of bones are covered with a thick layer of vascular fibrous tissue.

•    This layer is the periosteum and the nutrition of the underlying bone substance depends on the integrity of its blood vessels.

•    The periosteum is osteogenic, its deeper cells differentiating into osteoblasts when required.

•    In the growing individual, new bone is laid down under the periosteum.

•    The periosteum is united to the underlying bone by collagen (Sharpey’s) fibres, particularly strongly over the attachments of tendons and ligaments.

•    Periosteum does not, of course, cover the articulating surfaces of the bones in synovial joints; it is reflected from the articular margins to join the capsule of the joint.

•    Ligaments are composed of dense connective tissue, mainly collagen fibres, the direction of the fibres being related to the stresses which they undergo.

•    In general, ligaments are unstretchable, unless subjected to prolonged strain.

•    A few ligaments, such as the ligament flava between the vertebral laminae and ligamentum nuchae at the back of the neck, are made of elastic fibres, which enables them to stretch and regain their original length thereafter.

•    Ligaments are usually attached to bone at their two ends.

•    Tendons have a similar structure to collganeous ligaments, and attach muscle to bone.

•    They may be cylindrical, or flattened into sheet-like aponeuroses.

•    Tendons have a blood supply from vessels which descend from the muscle belly and anastomose with the periosteal vessels at the bony attachment.

questions.text: Enzyme common to glycolysis and gluconeogenesis is/are which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Phospho glycerate kinase

•    Phosphoglycerate kinase is reversible enzyme which catalyzes conversion of 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate and vivc versa . It is used in glycolysis as well as gluconeogenesis.

•    Phosphoenol pyruvate carboxykinase (PEPCK) is the enzyme needed for decarboxylation of OAA to produce PEP and is used in the process of gluconeogenesis alone.

•    Pyruvate kinase is the irreversible enzyme which converts phosphoenol pyruvate to pyruvate and is used in glycolysis alone

•    Phosphofructokinase-1 is the irreversible enzyme which converts fructose 6 to fructose 1,6 bisphosphate and is used in glycolysis alone.

questions.text: Boiled cabbage or rancid butter smelling urine is seen in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Tyrosinemia     

  • Tyrosinemia is an error of metabolism, inherited, which the body cannot effectively break down the amino acid tyrosine, found in most animal and plant proteins.
  • It is an autosomal recessive, which means two copies of an abnormal gene must be present in order for this to develop.
  • There are three types of tyrosinemia, each with distinctive symptoms and caused by the deficiency of a different enzyme.
  • One of the symptoms of Tyrosinemia type 1 is an odor like cabbage or rancid butter.

Closure of post- synaptic acetyl choline receptors
Closure of voltage-gated calcium channels on the pre- synaptic membrane

questions.text: 1. A single contraction of skeletal muscle is likely to be terminated by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Removal of sarcoplasmic calcium

Muscle contraction is tightly regulated by the amount of calcium in the sarcoplasm. As long as calcium is sufficiently high in the sarcoplasm, muscle will continue to be in a contracted state. None of the remaining events- removal of Ach from the synaptic cleft, closure of voltage-gated channels on the pre-synaptic membrane or closure of ligand-gated channels on the post synaptic membrane would have any effect on the contractile state of the muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following occurs at the end of isovolumetric relaxation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Opening of atrio-ventricular valves

Isovolumetric relaxation is the first phase of ventricular diastole. At the end of the isovolumetric relaxation phase the ventricular pressures become lower than the atrial pressures. This leads to opening of the atrio-ventricular valves and beginning of the filling phase.

questions.text: Which of the following substances will be most readily filtered by the glomerular capillaries?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Polycationic dextran with a molecular weight of 25,000

The filterability of a substance is inversely related to its molecular size or diameter and to its molecular weight. Also, positively charged substances are filtered more readily than neutral or negatively charged substances with the same molecular weight.

choices.text: Increase in the V/Q ratio of the left lung

questions.text: A child is eating round candies approximately 1.5 cm in diameter. He accidentally inhales ine down his airway, blocking his left bronchiole. All of the following changes will occur in this child except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increase in the V/Q ratio of the left lung

When an airway is blocked (as in this case, by a foreign body), the ventilation on the affected side decreases to zero, and therefore, the V/Q ratio will be zero.  The air in the alveoli reaches an equilibrium with the pulmonary arterial blood. Therefore, the alveolar Po2 will decrease to 40 mm Hg, and the alveolar Pco2 increases to 45 mm Hg. Since the blood in the pulmonary capillaries gets “shunted” without getting oxygenated, the systemic arterial Po2 will decrease.

questions.text: Which of the following will lead to absence of the stretch reflex in a skeletal muscle?

Sectioning of dorsal root of a spinal nerve

Stretch reflex is a spinal reflex. The center for the stretch reflex is in the spinal cord. Section of the dorsal root of the spinal nerve disrupts the reflex arc leading to absence of the reflex.

questions.text: Which one of the following is the hematopoietic stem cell mobilizer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hematopoietic stem cell mobilizer plerixafor, an inhibitor of the CXC chemokine receptor 4 (CXCR4). G-CSF is also used to mobilize peripheral blood stem cells in preparation for autologous and allogeneic stem cell transplantation.

Pegfilgrastim, a covalent conjugation product of filgrastim and a form of polyethylene glycol, has a much longer serum half-life than recombinant G-CSF

Oprelvekin (interleukin-11 [IL-11]) stimulates the growth of primitive megakaryocytic progenitors and increases the number of peripheral platelets. IL-11 is used for the treatment of patients who have had a prior episode of thrombocytopenia after a cycle of cancer chemotherapy

Eltrombopag is an oral agonist of the thrombopoietin receptor that is also used for patients with chronic idiopathic thrombocytopenia that is refractory to other agents

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with mental obtundation. He is found to have a blood pressure of 220/160 and retinal hemorrhages. Which one of the following is used in severe hypertensive emergencies, is short acting, acts by stimulating G-protein-coupled receptor, and must be given by intravenous infusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fenoldopam causes arterial/arteriolar vasodilation leading to a decrease in blood pressure by activating peripheral D1 receptors.  D1 receptor stimulation activates adenylyl cyclase and raises intracellular cyclic AMP, resulting in vasodilation of most arterial beds, including renal, mesenteric, and coronary arteries. to cause a reduction in systemic vascular resistance. Fenoldopam has a rapid onset of action (4 minutes) and short duration of action (< 10 minutes)

questions.text: A 54-year-old obese patient with type 2 diabetes has a history of alcoholism. In this patient, metformin should either be avoided or used with extreme caution because the combination of metformin and ethanol increases the risk of which of the following?

Biguanides, especially the older drug phenformin, have been associated with lactic acidosis. Thus, metformin should be avoided or used with extreme caution in patients with conditions that increase the risk of lactic acidosis, including acute ethanol ingestion

questions.text: A 27-year-old nursing mother is diagnosed as suffering from genital herpes. She has a history of this viral infection. Previously, she responded to a drug used topically. Apart from her current problem, she is in good health. Which drug to be used orally is most likely to be prescribed at this time?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Three of the drugs listed (foscarnet, trifluridine, valacyclovir) are active against strains of herpes simplex virus. Foscarnet is not used in genital infections (HSV-2) because clinical efficacy has not been established, it has poor oral bioavailability, and the drug causes many toxic effects. Trifluridine is used topically but only for herpes keratoconjunctivitis (HSV-1). Valacyclovir is converted to acyclovir by first-pass metabolism in the intestine and liver.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of vaginal itching and a malodorous discharge that is worse following her menses. She is sexually active with two partners and recently had unprotected sex. Pelvic examination shows erythema of the cervix and malodorous frothy yellow-green discharge present in the cervical os and vaginal vault. Microscopic examination of vaginal secretions shown in the image. Choose the correct infective stage of this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Trophozoite

  • Image and history suggestive of Trichomoniasis caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.
  • Trichomonas vaginalis is a flagellated protozoan parasite that causes the sexually transmitted disease trichomoniasis.
  • The vaginitis it causes is characterized as a thin frothy yellow-green, malodorous discharge.
  • Trichomoniasis also causes a spotty reddening of the mucosa that is referred to as colpitis macularis or "strawbeny cervix.’
  • The organism can be identified as motile trophozoites in methylene blue saline mounts of vaginal fluids by its characteristic twitching  motility.
  • Treatment - Metronidazole

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman who recently emigrated from Wuhan city comes to the emergency department because of severe right upper quadrant pain. An ultrasound of the gallbladder shows high echogenicity and she undergoes a cholecystectomy. Examination of the gallbladder shows a large number of dark-colored, faceted stones with irregular shapes Infection with which of the following organisms is most likely associated with this type of stone'?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • The stones described are pigment stones, composed of relatively pure calcium bilirubinate.
  • These stones are less common than cholesterol stones.
  • Risk factors for pigment stones include hepatic cirrhosis (unclear mechanism], hemolytic anemias, and liver fluke infection, notably by the Oriental/ Chinese  liver fluke Clonorchis sinensis.
  • Clonorchis sinensis is usually found in Asian countries.
  • C.sinensis is contracted when eggs hatches into miracidia in a freshwater snail [first intermediate host ] . The miracidia develop redia, then either develop into free-swimming cercaria or bore into a fish [2nd intermediate host]  in which they form metacercarial cysts, which is the infectious form for humans [definitive host), who consume the fish.
  • The mature flukes migrate to the liver and subsist on the bile.
  • None of the other options cause pathology in the biliary tract

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-week history of swollen and painful knees and toes. He also has some low back stiffness that is worse in the morning, and he has been treated recently for conjunctivitis He also describes an onset of urgency, clear urethral discharge and dysuria, which started five weeks ago. He is sexually active and has a monogamous relationship with the same person for the past 2 years. His vitals are normal. Which of the following is most likely to be found in this patient's history?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • This is a case of reactive arthritis (formerly Reiter syndrome}.
  • Patients typically present with the acute onset of arthritis (usually asymmetric and additive}, with involvement of new joints occurring over a period of a few days to 2 weeks. Joints of the lower extremities are the most commonly involved, but wrists and fingers can also be affected.
  • Dactylitis ("sausage digit"), a diffuse swelling of a solitary finger or toe, is a distinctive feature of reactive arthritis and psoriatic arthritis. Tendinitis and fasciitis are common. Spinal pain and low back pain are common.
  • Conjunctivitis, urethritis (dysuria, urgency, urethral discharge], diarrhea, and skin lesions are also associated with Reiter syndrome
  • Up to 15% of patients are HLA-B27-positive.
  • Microorganisms that can trigger this disease include Shigella sp, Salmonella sp.. Yersinia sp. Campylobacter jejuni, and Chlamydia trachomatis.
  • Most patients are younger males.

questions.text: A 69-year-old woman in a skilled nursing facility develops flulike symptoms. A rapid influenza test is positive. Several days later, she develops a high fever dyspnea a productive cough, and mental status changes. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary lesion in her left lung. Sputum specimen is salmon colored. Which of the following pathogen is the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

  • This woman has developed a pulmonary abscess, as evidenced by the chest radiograph.
  • Of the organisms listed, Staphylococcus aureus is the most likely cause of bacterial pneumonia complicated by abscess formation.
  • Bacteria that commonly produce pneumonia that develops in the context of influenza include S. aureus, Haemophilus influenzae, and Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • Of these, S. aureus is the most destructive to lung tissue and likely to cause cavitary lesions.
  • S. aureus is a gram-positive, catalase-positive, coagulase-positive coccus.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of mild lower abdominal pain and non-malodorous vaginal discharge for the past week. Pelvic examination shows a red swollen cervix without motion tenderness. Examination of the discharge with potassium hydroxide (KOH) is negative, no clue cells under the microscope, and a wet mount does not show motile cells. Gram stain of the discharge shown in the image. Which of the following is the most important factor in the pathogenesis of the most likely causal organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

  • The symptoms suggest a cervical infection (cervicitis) with pathogens such as Neisseria gonorrhea, Chlamydia trachomatis, Trichomonas, or Gardenella.
  • Of these, Neisseria is the only one that would produce a neutrophilic discharge containing gram-negative diplococci.
  • The other pathogens are ruled out based on findings of the gram stain, the absence of clue cells and motile cells.
  • Gram negative intracellular kidney shaped diplococci.
  • The most important mechanism of pathogenesis for N. gonorrhoeae is the possession of pili.
  • In this infection, the pili promote adherence to the mucosa and protection from phagocytosis, and undergo antigenic variation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy with a history of acute lymphoblastic leukemia is brought to the physician by his mother because of a painful rash lasting for the past 3 days. He is currently being treated with chemotherapy. His birth history is significant for his mother having an illness that caused her to develop malaise pruritus and a diffuse rash during her third trimester. Physical examination shows lesions in different stages with some as vesicles on an erythematous base and others as crusted lesions. They are all distributed unilaterally, in a dermatomal distribution. A photograph ofthe rash is shown. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the development of these symptoms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • The rash shown in the image is clearly unilateral and follows a dermatome, which is diagnostic of the rash of shingles, the secondary manifestation of infection with the Varicella zoster virus (HHV3).
  • After the initial episode of chickenpox (primary infection),. the varicella zoster virus causes a latent infection in the sensory ganglia.
  • If the latent virus is reactivated, shingles develops.
  • The majority of cases of chickenpox present in children, who will show an asynchronous pruritic rash consisting of papules, vesicles, pustules, and crusted lesions in crops in various stages.
  • Vital signs will usually be normal.
  • Shingles presents in the elderly population as unilateral painful vesicles, usually restricted to one dermatome.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by his parents for right arm pain. The patient reports that he was playing hide and seek outside and felt a sharp pain on his arm while hiding in some thick bushes. His parents suspect that something had stung him. Physical examination shows an edematous and erythematous plaque with mild central pallor. A residual stinger, located central to the lesion, is readily extracted. The physical examination is other wise not significant. Which of the following substances is most likely directly responsible for the skin findings observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

  • This child is experiencing a local allergic reaction (type I hypersensitivity) to an insect sting.
  • The cutaneous findings are consistent with a wheal-and-flare reaction, an erythematous papule or plaque often with central pallor (wheat) and peripheral erythema (flare).
  • During initial allergen exposure, a patient predisposed to an allergic response will undergo antibody class switching from lgM to lgE antibodies specific for the allergen.
  • lgE produced by B lymphocytes and plasma cells then binds to high-affinity lgE Fc receptors on basophils and mast cells.
  • Re-exposure to the allergen results in cross-linking of bound lgE antibodies with subsequent degranulation and release of inflammatory mediators (eg, histamine, proteases [tryptase], leukotrienes, prostaglandins).
  • Localized vasodilation and increased vascular permeability result in the characteristic wheal-and-flare lesions.
  • In severe cases, widespread release of these agents can also cause systemic vasodilation, bronchoconstriction, and massive fluid shifts, leading to anaphylactic shock and potentially death.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with AIDS develops a fever, headache and a stiff neck. Examination of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) shows 100 cells, which are mostly lymphocytes, glucose of 35 mg/dL, and protein of 75 mg/dL. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm this patient's diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

  • This patient has symptoms and signs of a fungal cerebrospinal infection.
  • The most common cause of meningitis in AIDS patients is Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an encapsulated, monomorphic yeast acquired from exposure to pigeon droppings.
  • The most sensitive test that is used to diagnose Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis is the Latex particle agglutination to detect capsular antigens shed into the CSF
  • Although India ink test of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) also useful but India ink is not the preferred diagnostic test for Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis since it misses about 50% of all infections.
  • Induction therapy for Cryptococcus neoformans meningitis should consist of amphotericin B plus flucytosine for at least six to ten weeks or until afebrile and culture negative.

•    Thresholds can be estimated without any electrical tests. The non-invasive brainstem evoked response (BSER) or cortical electrical response audiometry (CERA) are more widely used than ECochG.

•    It is a useful objective test provided it is used in conjunction with other audiological investigations.

questions.text: Choose the most appropriate statement regarding the tonsil shown in the image below
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

There are no afferent lymphatics.

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

•    Non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium covers the pharyngeal surface and extends into all the crypts.

•    Desquamated cells form part of the crypt debris which can be seen as white or yellow spots.

•    The tonsil acts as an initial antigen processing station for swallowed material, some of which is trapped in the crypts. Efferent lymphatics drain to the jugulo-digastric node.

•    The tonsillar artery is a branch of the facial. There are some minor branches from the greater palatine which may supply the upper pole. Further blood supply is obtained from small branches of the lingual and ascending pharyngeal arteries.

•    Some tonsils appear large because the tonsillar fossae are shallow, while others of similar or greater mass may be almost completely buried. In addition, contraction of the pharyngeal musculature can bring the tonsils closer to the midline, so the apparent size is variable in the individual patient.

questions.text: 50-year-old male patient is referred to clinic with a long-standing history of sneezing and rhinorrohea made worse after eating or drinking. Anterior rhinoscopy shows the following appearance of his left nostril.Which of the following nerve is responsible for such presentation:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

5th .

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

•    Gustatory rhinitis which is a subgroup of non-allergic rhinitis.

•    This is thought to be due to stimulation of the trigeminal nerve in the upper aerodigestive tract (usually in response to spicy foods), which causes a corresponding increase in parasympathetic nerve activity to the nasal mucosa (similar in nature to Frey syndrome).

•    There are four identified subtypes of gustatory rhinitis: idiopathic, post-traumatic, post-surgery and gustatory rhinitis associated with cranial nerve palsies.

There is no diagnostic test but often allergy tests (skin prick tests/Radioallergosorbent test) are performed to help exclude allergic rhinitis

questions.text: A 6-year-old child sustains a mild concussion and reports new hearing loss and po-sitional dizziness. An audiogram shows a unilateral flat 70-dB sensorineural hearing loss, and CT scan demonstrates a Mondini deformity. The most likely diagnosis is:

Perilymph fistula

Ref: Read the text below.

Sol:-

•    Mondini deformity has a higher likelihood of trauma causing leakage of CSF and perilymph from the inner to middle ear.    

•    BPPV and labyrinthine concussion do not entail hearing loss.

•    Cochlea concussion, an option not offered, describes hearing loss from trauma.

questions.text: 62-year-old gentleman with a long-standing history of a weak voice is attending the voice clinic for an injection of the a drug. Which type of toxin is most commonly used in medical practice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Types A and B

Ref:Read the text below

Sol:

Botulinum toxin is a neurotoxin released by Clostridium botulinum and prevents release of the neurotransmitter acetylcholine from axons at the neuromuscular junction. It therefore results in accid paralysis of skeletal muscle, smooth muscle and the secretion of some glands. It is used clinically to either paralyse muscles (that may be overactive) or reduce secretions from glands. There are various types, A to G with types A and B most commonly used in medical practice.

•    Frey syndrome: This is caused secondary to parotid surgery whereby eating/ thinking of eating causes sweating and erythema of the skin overlying the parotid gland. This is due to aberrant parasympathetic reinnervation of the skin sweat glands from the dissected parotid gland. Botulinum toxin can be injected into the a ected area to paralyse this a ect.

•    Spasmodic dysphonia: This can be for either adduction or abduction spasmodic dysphonia. The type of dysphonia dictates which muscles of the larynx are injected to reduce their activity.

•    Blepharospasm, torticollis and hemifacial spasm can be treated with botulinum toxin, but are often managed by neurologists.

•    It may also be used to relax the cricopharyngeus muscle in patients with dysphagia due to cricopharyngeal spasm and in post-laryngectomy patients who have pharyngo-oesophageal spasm resulting in failure of tracheo-oesophageal speech.

•    Sialorrhoea in those with Parkinson’s disease or with cerebral palsy can be treated with botulinum toxin as can palatal and stapedial myoclonus.

questions.text: A 67-year-old woman is admitted to the casualty with pyrexia (38.1) and a cough productive of green sputum. The observations show a Pulse rate of 101/min, BP 80/60 and Respiratory rate of 32/min. She is alert and oriented in time and space. Investigations reveal TLC of 21000, Urea of 8.5 and x-ray reveals consolidation in the right lung. She is treated for CAP. Which of the following is the correct calculated CURB 65 score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Total score is 4.

CURB65 criteria is a prognostic score for cases of community acquired pneumonia. It is provided by BTS (British Thorasic society) It consists of following parameters, the presence of each is given 1 point. The maximum score possible is 5.

C    -    Confusion

U    -    Elevated Urea > 7.1 mmol/L

R    -    Respiratory rate > 30/min

B    -    BP < 90/60mm of Hg

65    -    Age > 65 years

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman has Bout onset multiple sclerosis. She has experienced two attacks of disease previously that have left her with residual lower extremity weakness. She was initially treated with glucocorticoids with some improvement in her symptoms. However, she is currently only able to walk with a rolling walker about 100 m. A prior antibody test shows that she is positive for reactivity to the JC virus. You are planning to start a disease-modifying therapy. Which of the following is LEAST appropriate for this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Natalizumab is not recommended in this patient due to the presence of antibody to JC virus. About half of the population is antibody positive for JC virus, indicating past exposure typically with an asymptomatic infection. JC virus is implicated in the development of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy. This life-threatening condition has occurred in 0.3% of all patients treated with natalizumab and in about 0.6% of patients who are positive for JC virus antibody. The risk is lower in the first year of treatment and increases thereafter. Thus, natalizumab should not be used in this patient unless she has failed alternative therapies or if the disease course has been particularly aggressive.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female non-smoker presented with sudden onset of cough followed by breathlessness. CXR revealed pneumothorax. She also gives history of similar episodes in the past. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pulmonary LAM

•    Pulmonary Lymphangioleiomyomatosis is a rare, progressive and systemic disease that typically results in cystic lung destruction.

•    It predominantly affects women, especially during childbearing years.

•    It is a neoplasm of smooth muscle spindle.

•    Majority present with shortness of breath with recurrent spontaneous pneumothorax in a non-smoker female.

•    Sirolimus is an mTOR inhibitor that stabilizes lung function and improves some measures of life in LAM patients.

•    Lung transplant offers potential cure but there is a risk of recurrence in the graft making the overall prognosis poor.

questions.text: A post-menopausal female presented with sudden onset angina. Coronary Angiography revealed normal vessels. Ventriculography performed in this patient during systole revealed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy – Stress induced cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) is a unknown etiology transient myocardial ischemia syndrome common in postmenopausal females especially after intense emotional stimulus. Patients often present with chest pain, have ST-segment elevation on electrocardiography (ECG), and have elevated cardiac enzyme levels consistent with myocardial infarction (MI). However, when the patient undergoes cardiac angiography, left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning (as seen in the Question image – Takotsubo) is present, and there is no significant coronary artery stenosis.

The Japanese word takotsubo translates to "octopus pot," resembling the shape of the left ventricle during systole on imaging studies.

questions.text: A 45- year- old man fell on the ground with  all of his extremities showing increased in tone with subsequent jerking followed by loss of consciousness  . Which of the following best characterizes his new condition?

questions.text: An 80 years old man with past history of AMI is found to have LBBB on ECG. He is asymptomatic; on cardiac auscultation the most likely finding is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Second heart sound (S2) is composed of aortic closure followed by pulmonic closure. Because inspiration increases blood return to the right side of heart, pulmonic closure is delayed which results in normal splitting of S2 during inspiration. Paradoxical or reverse splitting of S2 refers to narrowed splitting of S2 during inspiration as compared with expiration because pulmonic closure precedes aortic closure. It can occur in the following - LBBB, Aortic stenosis, HOCM, severe hypertension, and RV pacemaker.

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:

ph – 7.23

PaCO2 – 70 mm

HCO3 – 25 mEq
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Acute Respiratory Acidosis

The ABG shows Primary Respiratory acidosis. To differentiate we need to look at the relation to change in pH with change in PaCO2 in Acute vs Chronic disease.

In Acute Respiratory acidosis, there is no time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.4 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.

In Chronic Respiratory acidosis, there is time for Metabolic compensation (which occurs over weeks to months) and hence the drop in pH is 0.1 for every 10mm increase in PaCO2.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man with a 6-year history of HIV-AIDS complicated recently by PCP was treated with high dose Co-Trimoxazole. On day 4 of treatment, the following laboratory data was obtained as follows: Na+ -135, K+-6.5, Cl-110, HCO3-15, pH-7.30, BUN-14, Creatinine-0.9, Plasma Osmolarity - 268. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Non-Anion gap metabolic acidosis:

One of the causes is Drug induced due to competitive inhibition of aldosterone by Trimethoprim (Part of cotrimoxazole) leading to Type 4 RTA.
Step wise approach :

1.pH is 7.30= acidosis

2.HCO3 is 15(low); pH and Hco3 change same direction= metabolic acidosis

3.AG (Anion Gap) = (Na+) - (Cl- + HCO3--) = 135-(110+15)=10; normal anion gap.

choices.text: Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Acidosis
Metabolic Acidosis with Additional Respiratory Alkalosis
Respiratory alkalosis with compensatory metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
Interpret the following ABG:

ph – 7.20

PaO2 – 69mm

PaCO2 – 30 mm

HCO3 – 15 mEq
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Metabolic Acidosis with Compensatory respiratory Alkalosis

Compensation in case of Metabolic acidosis i.e. expected change in CO2 due to acidosis is calculated using Winter’s formula: (1.5*Pts HCO3 value) + 8 +/- 2.

In the given question, the ph is 7.20 indicating acidosis. (Hence NOT Option D)

HCO3 is less than normal indicating Primary Metabolic acidosis.

According to Winter’s formula: Expected PaCO2 in this patient should be 30+/-2 mm.

Since the PaCO2 in the report is as expected, there is no additional respiratory defect and the change in PaCO2 (i.e. Respirator Alkalosis) is compensatory to the primary defect.

choices.text: Normal–anion-gap metabolic acidosis + High anion gap acidosis
Normal–anion-gap metabolic acidosis and compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.text: An 84-year-old female was found to have a blood pressure of 85/60 mmHg, heart rate 101beats/min, temperature 37.8°C. Laboratory data are obtained: sodium 137 meq/L, potassium 2.8meq/L, HCO3 10 meq/L, chloride 117 meq/L, BUN 17 mg/dL, creatinine 0.9 mg/dL. An arterial blood gas shows PaO2 80 mmHg, PCO2 24 mmHg, pH 7.29. Her urine analysis is clear and has a Ph of 4.5. What is the acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

NAGMA and compensatory respiratory alkalosis.

Steps in ABG:

1. See the pH: Acidosis or Alkalosis

2. Check for primary disorder: Respiratory or metabolic

3. See for compensation.

a.IF primary was respiratory process , calculate metabolic compensation. If primary was metabolic calculate respiratory compensation

b. If given value is within the expected value then it is a simple acid base disorder

c. If given value is not correlating with expected value then it will be a inappropriate compensation / mixed disorder.

4. Calculate Anion gap

In given case, Acidosis is correlating more to fall in HCO3 so its metabolic acidosis.

Expected PaCO2 = [1.5 × HCO3] +8 +-2 that give the value of 21 to 25mmhg. Here the given PaCO2 is correlating with expected value which will suggest metabolic acidosis and compensatory alkalosis. Anion gap is also with in normal range (10-12meq)

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of Lactic Acidosis- Type A?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cardiac failure

Lactic acidosis – Type A is due to anaerobic metabolism secondary to poor tissue perfusion. Cardiac failure leading to shock is a common cause.

Malignancy, Drug use (NNRTI in HIV), Drug toxicity (Methanol, polyethylene glycol,etc), Thiamine deficiency, DM, Renal failure,etc  can also cause Lactic acidosis without anaerobic state. These are classified as Lactic acidosis – Type B.

choices.text: Idiopathic PAH is more common in middle aged females

PAH is a dreaded manifestation causing mortality in Scleroderma patients

questions.text: Identify the false statement about Pulmonary arterial hypertension
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure is > 20mm of Hg

Idiopathic (isolated) PAH is a precapillary cause of Pulmonary hypertension affecting middle aged females. PCWP is < 20mm of Hg as it is a pre-capillary cause.

PAH can also occur along with HIV, Autoimmune disease and Drug use.
In Scleroderma, PAH is a dreaded complication. PAH can be treated with oral endothelin receptor antagonists (Bosentan, Ambrisentan – convenient oral route but modest efficacy only) as first line when disease is uncomplicated and mild. In PAH with Heart failure, the first line treatment consists of parenteral prostacyclin derivatives which are more potent. Lung transplant is the only potential cure.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about cardiac tamponade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Pulsus paradoxus is defined as a fall of systolic blood pressure of >10 mmHg during the inspiratory phase. Pulsus paradoxus can be observed in cardiac tamponade and in conditions where intrathoracic pressure swings are exaggerated or the right ventricle is distended, such as severe acute asthma or exacerbations of COPD.

•    Electrical alternans is defined as alternating QRS amplitude that is seen in any or all leads on an electrocardiogram (ECG) with no additional changes to the conduction pathways of the heart. This rhythm is typically associated with pericardial effusion via the “swinging heart” from the fluid surrounding the heart. However, electrical alternans is also associated with other pathologies including but not limited to ventricular tachycardia, Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW), accelerated idioventricular rhythm, and supraventricular tachycardia

•    In cardiac tamponade there is prominent x descent and absent y descent

o    Friedreich’s sign, originally coined Friedreich’s diastolic collapse of the cervical veins, describes a sharp and deep y descent of the jugular venous waveform. It can be a clue to the diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis.

questions.text: A young female presented with a swelling in the anterior neck for last 3 months. About 10 years ago she was treated for Lymphoma by neck radiotherapy. On examination her vitals are stable, a single firm nodule was palpable in anterior neck which moves with deglutition. Which of the following is a false statement about this condition?

PAPILLARY CARCINOMA: 75%

•    Peak onset ages 30 - 50

•    Females more common than males by 3 to 1 ratio

•    Accounts for 85% of thyroid cancers due to radiation exposure

•    Spread to lymph nodes of the neck present in more than 50% of cases

•    Distant spread (to lungs or bones) is very uncommon

•    Overall cure rate very high (near 100% for small lesions in young patients)

•    Characterized by infiltrative pattern, multicentricity (80%) and node spread.

•    Nuclear membrane has ground glass appearance (Orphan Annie appearance).

•    Mixed follicular and papillary variant is classified as papillary type.

•    Even if occult papillary cancer metastasize to local nodes, prognosis is still excellent. Extrathyroid extension and distant metastasis worsens the prognosis.

•    Lymph node metastasis is not a poor prognostic sign in most of the thyroid carcinomas. It is poor prognostic in medullary thyroid carcinoma.

Torus mandibularis. Tori are bony extoses, usually seen on the center of the hard palate as torus palatini attached to the mandible. They are usually asymptomatic but may cause dental problems, such as in fitting dentures or braces, and have no potential for malignancy.

questions.text:
An 75 year-old man was admitted with a 4 week history of abdominal pain, weight loss and diarrhoea. On physical examination cutaneous hyperpigmentation and alopecia was found. Laboratory data showed mild hypoalbuminaemia (3·6 g/dL [normal range 3·9–4·9]); all other parameters were within normal limits. Oesophago-gastroduodenoscopy and colonoscopy were done and multiple small reddish polypoid lesions were seen mainly at the gastric antrum, ascending colon, and caecum

Tissue biopsies of the polypoid lesions were taken, and pathological examination showed expansion of the crypt and infiltration of the lamina propria by inflammatory cells, without neoplastic changes.

What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Cronkhite-Canada syndrome (CCS) is an extremely rare disease characterized by various intestinal polyps, loss of taste, hair loss, and nail growth problems. It is difficult to treat because of malabsorption that accompanies the polyps.

The symptoms of Cronkhite-Canada syndrome occur because of multiple polyps occurring in the stomach, small intestine, colon and, less frequently, the esophagus. These include chronic or recurring watery diarrhea, cramps, and abdominal discomfort. These people may also have abnormally low levels of protein in the blood (protein-losing enteropathy), causing a feeling of general ill health (cachexia), malnutrition, nausea and vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fracture shown in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The neurological complications are transitory

Ref: Apley’s ‘Textbook of Orthopaedics and Fractures’; 9/e, Chap 24

Sol:

SUPRACONDYLAR FRACTURES

•    These are among the commonest fractures in children.

•    The distal fragment may be displaced either posteriorly or anteriorly.

MECHANISM OF INJURY:

•    Posterior angulation or displacement (95 per cent of all cases) suggests a hyperextension injury, usually due to a fall on the outstretched hand.

•    The humerus breaks just above the condyles.

•    The distal fragment is pushed backwards and (because the forearm is usually in pronation) twisted inwards.

•    The jagged end of the proximal fragment pokes into the soft tissues anteriorly sometimes injuring the brachial artery or median nerve.

•    Anterior displacement is rare (option ‘1’); it is thought to be due to direct violence (e.g. a fall on the point of the elbow) with the joint in flexion.

CLINICAL FEATURES:

•    Following a fall, the child is in pain and the elbow is swollen; with a posteriorly displaced fracture the S-deformity of the elbow is usually obvious and the bony landmarks are abnormal.

•    It is essential to feel the pulse and check the capillary return; passive extension

•    of the flexor muscles should be pain-free.

•    The wrist and the hand should be examined for evidence of nerve injury.

•    The fracture is seen most clearly in the lateral view.

•    In an undisplaced fracture the ‘fat pad sign’ should raise suspicions: there is a triangular lucency in front of the distal humerus, due to the fat pad being pushed forwards by a haematoma.

•    The radial nerve, median nerve (particularly the anterior interosseous branch) or the ulnar nerve may be injured.

•    Fortunately loss of function is usually temporary and recovery can be expected in 3 to 4 months (option ‘3’).

•    If there is no recovery the nerve should be explored.

•    However, if a nerve, documented as intact prior to manipulation, is then found to have failed after manipulation, then entrapment in the fracture is suspected and immediate exploration should be arranged.

COMPLICATIONS:

•    Malunion is common.

•    However, backward or sideways shifts are gradually smoothed out by modelling during growth and they seldom give rise to visible deformity of the elbow.

•    Forward or backward tilt may limit flexion or extension, but consequent disability is slight.


•    Weakness of elbow extension is commonly observed (option ‘4’).

•    Uncorrected sideways tilt (angulation) and rotation are much more important and may lead to varus (or rarely valgus) deformity of the elbow (option ‘2’); this is permanent and will not improve with growth (gun-stock deformity).

•    The fracture is extra-physeal and so physeal damage should not be blamed for the deformity; usually it is faulty reduction which is responsible.

•    Cubitus varus is disfiguring and cubitus valgus may cause late ulnar palsy.

•    If deformity is marked, it will need correction by supracondylar osteotomy usually once the child approaches skeletal maturity.

questions.text: Steps in the operative correction of congenital talipes equinovarus include all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Release of peroneus brevis from its insertion

  • The crucial component in CTEV is subluxation of the talonavicular joint. The soft tissues on the medial side of the foot are underdeveloped and shorter than normal.
  • Aim of treatment is to set the tarsal bones in normal relationship to one another and to relieve deforming stresses thus allowing the bones to develop in their normal shape from an early age.
  • All taut ligaments at the medial side of the ankle and foot are divided and any tendon that is too tight to allow full correction is lengthened including the calcaneal tendon (tendoAchilles).
  • Finally the tarsal bones thus released are restored to their normal relationships, particular attention being paid to the talus and navicular bone.
  • The peroneus brevis is present on the lateral side of the foot and is an evertor; hence it is not released.

questions.text: A 37-year-old patient with a history of acute intermittent porphyria is scheduled for knee arthroscopy under general anesthesia. Which of the following drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

•    Acute intermittent porphyria is the most serious form of porphyria. This disease affects both the central and peripheral nervous systems.

•    An acute intermittent porphyria attack can be triggered by a variety of conditions, including starvation, dehydration, stress, sepsis, and some drugs, such as etomidate and barbiturates.

•    Drugs that are safe or probably safe include local anesthetics, inhaled anesthetics, neuromuscular blocking drugs, some intravenous anesthetics (propofol), some analgesics (acetaminophen, aspirin, morphine, fentanyl, sufentanil), antiemetics (droperidol, H2 blockers, metoclopramide, ondansetron), and neostigmine and naloxone.

•    Drugs that are contraindicated include some intravenous anesthetics (barbiturates, etomidate, ketamine), some analgesics (ketorolac, pentazocine), and hydantoin anticonvulsants

Based on physical status, the patients are classified into six categories by American Society of Anesthesiologist.

The morbidity and mortality are highest in grade V patients and minimum in grade I patients.

I: Normal healthy patient

II: Mild systemic disease not limiting functional activity

III: Severe systemic disease that limits the activity but not incapacitating

IV: Incapacitating disease that is a constant threat to life

V: Moribund patient who is not going to survive for more than 24 hours Without operation

VI: Brain dead patients (for organ donation)

DRAWBACK OF ASA CLASSIFICATION:

Doesn’t consider surgical risk.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old male is posted for an emergency incision and drainage of a neck abscess. The patient was very anxious and therefore the surgeon demanded general anaesthesia for the patient. Since the procedure was short, the anaesthesiologist decided to use succinylcholine and intubate the patient with cuffed endotracheal tube. The patient received 80 mg of succinylcholine for intubation and following the procedure the patient was apneic for over an hour. The patient was shifted to ICU and was kept on controlled ventilation.

Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

•    This is a case of prolonged apnea following succinylcholine usage.

•    Normal duration of action of scoline is 3-10 mins.

•    Scoline is metabolized by plasma cholinesterase enzyme aka pseudocholinesterase\butyrlcholinestrase.

•    Prolonged duration of action of Scoline can be due to multiple factors:

1)    Decrease in plasma cholinesterase enzyme ( eg: liver disease\renal disease\pregnancy\cholinesterase inhibitor): duration prolonged to twice the time [ up to 20 mins]

2)    Phase II blockade: due to large dose (>7 – 10 mg\kg) or long duration (> 60 mins). Duration of action: unpredictable (> 10 mins).

3)    Atypical pseudocholinesterase enzyme: genetic variant in the enzyme which causes delayed metabolism of scoline.

•    Depending on the level of atypicality the duration of action changes.

•    Atypical pseudocholinesterase activity is measured by DIBUCAINE Number.

•    Dibucaine is a long acting local anesthetic that inhibits normal pseudocholinesterase enzyme by 80% and atypical by 20 %.

•    It is a qualitative assessment of enzyme function.

•    Heterozygous atypical will have dibucaine number between 40-60 and the duration is prolonged up to 20 mins

•    Homozygous atypical enzyme is a rare condition with dibucaine number between 20-40 and duration is prolonged up to 3-6 hours

•    Management of this apnea is mechanical ventilation and sedation.

questions.text: Which of the following is a dose-dependent side-effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Agranulocytosis can occur at any given dose of clozapine. It is not a dose-dependent effect. The risk of agranulocytosis is higher in the fi rst year of clozapine therapy and gradually reduces over the course of treatment. Similarly, neuroleptic malignant syndrome is an idiosyncratic reaction which cannot be predicted in an individual patient. The most important clinical implication to remember is the fact that if a patient has an idiosyncratic side-effect, then this can reoccur at even small doses if rechallenged. Stopping the drug rather than lowering its dose is the appropriate management strategy in such cases. Naltrexone produces hepatocellular damage in proportion to the dose administered, especially in patients with pre-existing liver damage.

questions.text: A 4-year-old girl is brought to her pediatrician because her parents think she does not seem to be “developing normally.” The girl’s mother states that her daughter seemed normal for at least the first 2 to 3 years of her life. She was walking and beginning to speak in sentences. She was able to play with her mother and older sister. The mother has been noticing that over the past 2 months her daughter has lost these previously acquired abilities. She will no longer play with anyone else and has stopped speaking entirely. She has lost all bowel control, when previously she had not needed a diaper for at least a year. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Childhood disintegrative disorder

Childhood disintegrative disorder is characterized by apparently normal development through at least the first 2 years of life. During this time, age-appropriate skills such as verbal and nonverbal communication, social relationships, bowel and bladder control, and play all develop normally. The disease manifests itself as a clinically significant loss of previously acquired skills before the age of 10. In Rett disorder, the onset of the disease occurs earlier, usually 6 months after birth, and there are characteristic hand stereotypies that do not occur in childhood disintegrative disorder. The presence of the apparently normal  development of speech and other behaviors, followed by the loss of these, distinguishes this disorder from autism and Asperger disorder where there is no loss of previously acquired skills.

questions.text: An attractive and well-dressed 22-year-old woman is arrested for prostitution, but on being booked at the jail, she is found to actually be a male. The patient tells the consulting physician that he is a female trapped in a male body and he has felt that way since he was a child. He has been taking female hormones and is attempting to find a surgeon who would remove his male genitals and create a vagina. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Transexualism

In adolescents and young adults, gender identity disorder is characterized by strong crossgender identification, a persistent discomfort with one’s sex, and clinically significant distress or impairment. Such patients usually trace their conviction to early childhood, often live as the opposite sex, and seek sex reassignment surgery and endocrine treatment. These patients feel a sense of relief and appropriateness when they are wearing opposite-sex clothing. In contrast, patients with transvestic fetishism are sexually aroused by this behavior, and so typically only seek to wear clothing of the opposite sex during sexual situations. Homosexuality is not a diagnosis in DSM-IV. While some homosexuals cross-dress to seek a same-sex partner, they do not feel that they belong to the opposite sex, nor do they seek sex reassignment surgery. Seeking surgery points to transexualism

questions.text: Test used for organic brain syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Bender gestalt test

choices.text: Oxytocin contracts upper and lower segment of the uterus
Oxytocin is stored in room temperature
Carbetocin has longer half-life than oxytocin
Ergometrine can be used in contraction stress test to detect uteroplacental insufficiency

questions.text: Which one of the following is true regarding uterotonics?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Carbetocin has longer half-life than oxytocin

Oxytocin contracts only the upper segment of the uterus, it does not contract the lower segment. Oxytocin storage is at 2-8-degree Celsius. Oxytocin has a half life of 3-5 minutes while carbetocin is a long acting oxytocin with half life of 45 minutes. Ergometrine is not used in CST, oxytocin is used for the same.

choices.text: More pregnancies abort than those which continue till term
Most common abortion is first trimester abortion
Most common karyotype of abortus is euploid (50%)
Most common chromosomal abnormality causing abortion is trisomy

questions.text: Which one of the following is not correct regarding abortions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

More pregnancies abort than those which continue till term

The incidence of abortion is 15-20% which means most of the pregnancies continue till term. T1 abortions are 80-90 % of all the abortions. Chromosomal abnormalities are causative in 50% abortions while 50 % abortions are euploid abortions. Most common chromosomal abnormality is trisomy.

questions.text: A 27 years old primigravida with missed period, her UPT is positive, USG is suggestive of 2 cm gestational sac in left adnexa with no fetal cardiac activity and no free fluid in pouch of Douglas. Her B-HCG is 1289 IU/L. Her pulse is 82/minute and BP is 110/70mm Hg. She is a case of peptic ulcer disease and she is chronic alcoholic. Which one of the following is best for this patient amongst the given options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

laparoscopic salpingostomy

This is a case of unruptured ectopic pregnancy which generally requires methotrexate therapy for treatment but there is peptic ulcer disease and chronic alcoholism so methotrexate can’t be given. So, the best answer is laparoscopic salpingostomy in this case.

choices.text: Start tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutegravir irrespective of period of gestation and CD4 count
Start tenofovir, lamivudine and efavirenz irrespective of period of gestation and CD4 count
Start tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutegravir after first trimester since dolutegravir causes neural tube defects
Start tenofovir, lamivudine and efavirenz after 12 weeks for lifetime.

questions.text: A 32 years old primigravida is 6 weeks pregnant with single live intrauterine pregnancy. Her HIV test is positive and her CD4 count is 505 per microlitre. Which of the following is correct about the treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Start tenofovir, lamivudine and dolutegravir irrespective of period of gestation and CD4 count

As per the new NACO guideline of 2021, efavirenz is replaced by dolutegravir. So, TLD is to be started as soon as possible for lifetime.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct regarding progesterone?

1: It is used to prevent preterm labour in case of cervical shortening

2: It is used to treat preterm labour

3: It is used as emergency contraceptive

4: It is used to reverse endometrial hyperplasia without atypia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1,3 and 4 are correct

Isolated shortening of cervix is prone for preterm delivery so it is treated by progesterone support. Progesterone is not used in the actual treatment of preterm labour since it is a weak tocolytic. Progesterone called LNG 1500mcg one tablet within 3 days of intercourse is used as an emergency contraceptive. Progesterone is an anti-proliferative hormone and it causes atrophy of endometrium so it is used for reversing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.

questions.text: For fetal well-being evaluation in a case of GDM with macrosomia, which of the following test is not useful?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

USG doppler of umbilical artery

GDM with macrosomia is never associated with fetoplacental insufficiency so USG doppler is not useful in such cases. Other investigations mentioned are for fetal well-being evaluation in GDM.

choices.text: Give her antibiotics, steroids, MgSO4 and continue pregnancy till 34 weeks
Give her antibiotics, MgSO4 and deliver immediately
Give her antibiotics, MgSO4 and continue till 34 weeks
Give her antibiotics and deliver immediately

questions.text: A 27 years old G2P1L1 with 31 weeks of gestation, cephalic presentation has had rupture of membranes and she is leaking amniotic fluid since last 2 days. She is febrile. On examination, there is purulent discharge per vaginum with uterine tenderness. Fetal heart rate is 180 per minute. What is the correct line of management in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Give her antibiotics, MgSO4 and deliver immediately

This is a case of chorioamnionitis with PPROM. It requires antibiotics and prompt delivery. There is no scope of waiting in this case. MgSO4 is must in any preterm delivery of less than 32 weeks. Steroids are contra indicated in chorioamnionitis.

choices.text: Give steroids and continue till 38 weeks
Give steroids and do induction of labour immediately
Give steroids and do LSCS immediately.

questions.text: A 34-year-old primigravida has IUGR with abdominal circumference of the baby of 5th percentile. Her NST is reactive and AFI is 8cm and the baby is in cephalic presentation. She is having 33 weeks of gestation. Her USG doppler was done which showed normal umbilical artery flow. What should be our next plan of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Give steroids and continue till 38 weeks

This is a case of isolated mild IUGR. NST and AFI is normal and fetal weight is between 3-10th percentile so we can continue till 38-39 weeks. Had it been less than 3rd percentile then termination would have been at 37 weeks. Steroids are must in all cases expecting delivery before 37 weeks.  IUGR is not an indication of caesarean section, vaginal delivery is possible.

choices.text: It is more common when there is female foetus
It presents most commonly in first trimester with vomiting
Pregnancy can be continued till 38 weeks
Hypofibrinogenemia, thrombocytopenia, hypoglycaemia and hepatic encephalopathy are seen

questions.text: In acute fatty liver of pregnancy, which one of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypofibrinogenemia, thrombocytopenia, hypoglycaemia and hepatic encephalopathy are seen

AFLP is seen more commonly in pregnancies with male fetus. It is more common in third trimester. It is life threatening condition so there is no scope of expectant management till 38 weeks. Immediate delivery is required. 90% cases undergo caesarean section. Liver dysfuntion leads to hyperammonemia, hypofibrinogenemia, hypoglycemia, hepatic encephalopathy and in 20 % cases there is thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: A 27 years old G4P3L3 patient had a full-term vaginal delivery. She developed hypotension and bradycardia after delivery. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Uterine inversion

Hypotension and bradycardia are seen together in neurogenic shock which is not seen in PPH and AF embolism. It is seen in uterine inversion.

questions.text: A 24 years old patient has 16 weeks of gestation with BP of 180/110mm Hg with urine albumin +4. Her BP was normal before pregnancy. USG is suggestive of snow storm appearance. She is a case of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Complete mole with pre-eclampsia

Pre-eclampsia is seen beyond 20 weeks of gestation except in a case of complete molar pregnancy where HTN can occur even before 20 weeks. There is significant proteinuria, hypertension and complete molar pregnancy in this case (snow storm appearance is seen in complete molar pregnancy)

choices.text: Advise her hysterectomy since invasive mole is a cancer
Give 4 doses of methotrexate therapy and advise her contraception for 1 year after HCG is undetectable
Give EMACO regimen and advise her contraception for 1 year after HCG is undetectable

questions.text: A 25-year-old female has invasive mole which is invading the outer half of myometrium. It has not gone beyond that. Her prognostic score is 5. She wants to conserve her fertility for future child bearing function. What is the best plan of action in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Give 4 doses of methotrexate therapy and advise her contraception for 1 year after HCG is undetectable

This is a case of low risk GTN (score <7) requiring fertility conservation. She is to be managed by single drug chemotherapy by MTx or ACT-D followed by HCG monitoring. Pregnancy is not allowed for 1 year in surveillance period.

It is never given intra venously

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the following drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It is most potent uterotonic for prevention of PPH

PGF2A is never given for prevention of PPH but it is given for treatment of PPH. 250mcg im is given every 15 minutes (max 8 doses). It causes bronchospasm so it is contraindicated in asthma. This drug is never given iv since it causes vasospasm and hypertension.

questions.text: Which of the following method of treatment is not suitable for endometrial hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Endometrial ablation

Mirena and DMPA are used for the treatment of hyperplasia without atypia while hysterectomy is used for hyperplasia with atypia (EIN). Ablation is not allowed in premalignant or malignant condition.

it is safe in patients with DVT

It is radio-opaque and it can be easily detected on x-ray. It is having least failure rate of 0.01 pearl index. It is contraindicated in breast cancer and DVT.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding endometrial ablation?

1: Second generation ablation technique is done without hysteroscopy

2: It is contraindicated in patient with past history of transmural myomectomy

3: It is done even in post-menopausal patients with bleeding due to endometrial atrophy
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1 and 2 are correct

First generation and second-generation ablation techniques differ by the use of hysteroscope in first generation and no use of hysteroscope in 2nd generation. It should not be done in previous classical caesarean or transmural myomectomy in past. It is not useful in post-menopausal patients with atrophy causing bleeding.

questions.text: A 65 years old post-menopausal patient has bleeding since last 2 months. Her Saline infused sonography revealed FIGO type 1 fibroid of 3 cm. What is the best plan of management in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Hysteroscopic myomectomy

Any patient with symptomatic fibroid of FIGO type 0 or 1 should be treated by hysteroscopic myomectomy even in post-menopausal patient

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the treatment of endometriosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pulsatile GnRH therapy

Endometriosis is treated medically by COC, progesterone, danazol, anastrazole, continuous GnRH agonist or antagonists but it is never treated by pulsatile GnRH therapy. Pulsatile therapy will activate HPO axis. Elagolix is a new drug for endometriosis. It is oral GnRH antagonist.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication of starting estrogen replacement therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Menopause at the age of 36 years

Premature menopause, vasomotor symptoms and urogenital atrophy are the approved indications of HRT. Osteoporosis is best treated by bisphosphonates. Menopause before 40 years is a premature menopause.

questions.text: A 13 years old girl has had menarche 3 months back. She has not got menses after her first period. What is not the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mc-Cune Albright syndrome

Mc CUNE ALBRIGHT syndrome is known for precocious puberty with production of exogenous estrogen. It is not responsible for secondary amenorrhoea.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in MRKH syndrome?
questions.solution:

Oligomenorrhoea

MRKH syndrome is Mullerian agenesis with failure of development of uterus and vagina. Ovaries are normal so there is ovulation and patient may get premenstrual syndrome like symptoms since her hormones are normal. Oligomenorrhoea is not seen amenorrhoea is seen in MRKH. Urinary tract anomalies are also seen.

questions.text: PCOS patients have increased risk of all the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PMS

PMS is seen in luteal phase of ovulatory cycles. It is not seen in anovulatory cycle which is hallmark of PCOS.

questions.text: Which one of the following is not useful in a case of Genuine stress urinary incontinence?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Urodynamic study

Urodynamic study is ordered if there is urgency incontinence or mixed incontinence. It has no role in genuine SUI.

questions.text: Which one of the following is included in LEVEL 3 pelvic organ support in DeLancey classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Deep transvesre perinei

LEVEL 3 is muscular support made up of pelvic floor muscles and perineal body. Deep transverse perinei is a part of pelvic floor muscle group.

Stage 2

questions.text:
Which of the following are indications for radioiodine treatment?

1. Relapsed Graves’ disease

2. Thyrotoxicosis in young children

3. Multinodular goitre

4. Severe ophthalmopathy

5. Pregnancy and lactation.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

1+3

Radioiodine treatment recommends the administration of enough radioiodine to achieve normal thyroid status. Hypothyroidism occurs in 15–20 per cent at 2 years. It is contraindicated in young children, pregnant and lactating mothers. It is the definitive choice of treatment in cases of relapsed Graves’ disease and in multinodular goitre and adenomas. One cause for concern is that radioactive iodine therapy has been associated with worsening Graves' ophthalmopathy. Radioiodine treatment carries a substantial risk of exacerbating pre-existing thyroid eye disease it should be avoided as far as possible in patients with active or severe ophthalmopathy.

questions.text: 10 year old girl presents with markedly elevated temperature and abdominal pain After seven days of intravenous antibiotics, her abdominal pain and fever persisted. A CT examination was obtained for further evaluation .Which of the following structures is affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Appendix

Non-contrast enhanced CT image of the abdomen  demonstrates the enlarged, inflamed appendix (small arrows) protruding into an anterior abdominal fluid collection representing an abscess (A).

questions.text: 70-year-old complains of abdominal pain of 2-month duration. A CT scan of the patient’s abdomen is shown below. An angiogram indicates that several arteries of the gastrointestinal tract are occluded due to atherosclerosis, producing bowel ischemia. Which of the following arteries is most likely occluded in the CT scan:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Left colic

►  The arrows in the CT scan point to the descending colon.

Therefore, the left colic artery, which supplies the descending colon, is the one most likely occluded in the CT scan.

The middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic artery supply the ascending colon, and the marginal artery provides an anastomosis between branches of the superior mesenteric artery and inferior mesenteric artery.

questions.text:
Brachytherapy: what is/are true?

A.    Always gives homogenous radiation

B.    Improve conformality by 3-D techniques

C.    Useful in carcinoma esophagus

D.    Same proportion of radiation as teletherapy in localised area

E.    More effective in Ca Cervix
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

B, C and E

Brachytherapy

•    Delivers higher amount of radiation in a localised area, with a better local control.

•    Large tumours are usually unsuited for use

•    Conformality of dose-delivery to target tissues is a major problem, to overcome which, newer 3-D conformal techniques are being developed (like 3D-IBT, a type of 3-dimensional interstitial brachytherapy), which have produced good results in cancer cervix.

•    Preferred in cancer cervix, uterus, vagina as well as breast, brain and esophageal cancers

•    Can be given intracavitary, interstitial or surface route

questions.text:
Which among the following are true regarding Strontium-89 as compared to Phosphorous-32?

A.    Str-89 is primarily a beta-rays emitter which P-32 is not

B.    Str-89 has deeper penetration

C.    Str-89 has a longer T1/2

D.    Str-89 is better suited than P-32 for palliation in metastasis

E.    Str-89 has lesser toxicity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

C, D and E

Explanation:

  • Recent trials and radiotherapy programmes prefer Str-89 over P-32 because of comparable efficacy and Str-89 having a better side effect profile than P-32 for palliation therapy in metastatic disease. P-32 causes severe myelotoxicity.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

0.1mg/kg or maximum dose of 6mgs

questions.text:
A 12 years old boy is lying unconscious on the road. On examination, he is pulseless and not breathing. An AED was brought, and CPR was started. This is the AED monitor screen:

What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

For pulseless VT/VF, give defibrillation 2J/kg

questions.text:
A neonate presents with a depressed nasal bridge, nail hypoplasia, seizures, and stippled bone epiphyses.

These findings are most likely a result from intrauterine exposure to which teratogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Warfarin

Intrauterine exposure to warfarin during 6-12 weeks’ gestation leads to clinical manifestations in 25% of neonates. These clinical findings include: a depressed nasal bridge, nasal hypoplasia, and stippled bone epiphyses. Infants may have low birthweight, seizure activity, and cognitive disabilities. If intrauterine exposure occurs after the 12th week of gestation, there is less of an impact on the fetus and neonate.

choices.text: Thin vermillion border of the upper lip

questions.text: You are asked to evaluate a term infant born to a mother with significant alcohol intake during the pregnancy. In addition to counseling the mother about potential adverse neurodevelopmental consequences in the infant, you discuss the physical examination features suggestive of fetal alcohol syndrome. All of the following physical examination findings can be associated with intrauterine alcohol exposure, EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Long palpebral fissures

Alcohol is one of the most common teratogens. Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is thought to occur in 0.5 to 2 per 1,000 live births in the United States, with disproportionately higher rates among African American and Native American populations. The most common features of a neonate with FAS include dysmorphic facies (e.g., short palpebral fissures, thin vermillion border of the upper lip, and a smooth philtrum), microcephaly, and growth restriction. Pregnant women who consume alcohol are at greater risk of having a small for gestational age infant.

Fetal alcohol exposure has the potential to affect multiple systems, resulting in cardiac (e.g., ventricular septal defect, tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis) and central nervous system abnormalities. The neurodevelopmental impairment has been shown to continue beyond infancy and lead to persistent learning difficulties. There are several hypotheses about the mechanism of teratogenesis of alcohol on the fetal brain, including:

-An apoptotic effect via blockade of NMDA glutamate receptors and activation of gammaaminobutyric acid (GABA) A receptors;

-Reduction in the fetus’ ability to respond to free radical damage; and

-Direct inhibition of Sonic hedgehog gene signaling.

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mortality in children between 1-59 months across the world?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumonia

questions.text: Which of the following is a marker for SAM in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Weight/height<-3SD is severe acute wasting

questions.text:
A 3-day old term infant develops abdominal distension and has not passed meconium. A barium contrast enema study reveals a narrowed segment of the colon with dilated bowel proximal to the involved segment.

Which of the following diseases is associated with a small left colon or microcolon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)

Both A and B – Maternal diabetes and maternal hypothyroidism

Microcolon in a newborn can be associated with maternal diabetes (most common association), maternal hypothyroidism, maternal toxemia, and prematurity. It can be a rare complication of cecal perforation. The pathogenesis of small left colon is postulated to result from a functional immaturity of the ganglion cells, primarily affecting the descending and rectosigmoid colon. This functional obstruction leads to abdominal distention and inability to pass meconium. A barium contrast enema study will show a small colon segment with dilated proximal bowel.

questions.text: Which of the following does NOT cross the placenta?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

TSH Thyroid-stimulating hormone

The placenta is a hormonally active organ, producing estrogens and human chorionic gonadotropin that stimulates triidodothyronine (T3) and thyroxine (T4). Both maternal T3 and T4 are partially permeable across the placenta. Although the amount of hormones transferred is low, this transfer is critical for the fetus because the fetal hypothalamic-pituitary axis is not well-developed in the first trimester and the fetus is not able to produce thyroid hormone until 18 to 20 weeks’ gestation.

Thyroid-releasing hormone, thyroid-stimulating hormone receptor antibodies, and iodide all freely cross the placenta. In contrast, thyroid-stimulating hormone does not cross the placenta.

questions.text:
A previously healthy male infant is being evaluated at 2-months of age because of hepatosplenomegaly and poor muscle tone. Ophthalmologic examination reveals clear corneas with macular cherry red spots.

Bone marrow biopsy would reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Foam cells

The child described in the vignette most likely has Niemann-Pick disease, Type A. This disease is a congenital lipidosis, caused by a lysosomal storage disease. It typically presents in the first month of life with hepatosplenomagaly and nervous system deterioration. Hallmarks include macular cherry red spots, clear corneas, and foam cells on bone marrow biopsy. Niemann-Pick disease Type B does not have ophthalmologic or central nervous system involvement. Both disorders result from a sphingomyelinase defect.

questions.text: Which of following is NOT X-linked recessive disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (F)

Hurler syndrome is autosomal recessive
